question: Walter...time for school, honey.
answer: Just ten more minutes --

question: Sorry, champ.
answer: It's cereal, it's supposed to be cold.

question: Hello? Yes, this is the supervisor, ma'am, what can I -- Yes, I can see that you're on a party line, ma'am, what can I -- I know, it's unfortunate, but people sometimes do listen in on party lines. We hope to have private lines installed by -- Well, what's he doing when you're on the phone? Are you sure? Maybe there's a problem with the phone line. He could be asthmatic, or -- Oh. No, I...I've never heard of anything like that before either. Guess there's a first time for everything, right? No, I'm afraid there's nothing we can do about people abusing the equipment or... themselves. I'm sorry. I --
answer: Everything all right?

question: Fine, Mr. Harris...fine...just someone having a problem with a... with the connection.
answer: Tell them to take the plug and shove it in and out a few times, that'll usually do it.

question: Unfortunately that was part of the problem. If you'll excuse me.... Hey, sport.
answer: Hey, mom.

question: So how was school?
answer: Okay. We learned about dinosaurs, and I got in a fight with Billy Mankowski.

question: What happened?
answer: He hit me.

question: Did you hit him back? Good. Rule number one
answer: Because I hit him.

question: Wait...you hit him first? Why?
answer: He said my dad ran off because he didn't like me.

question: Your dad never even had a chance to meet you...so how could he not like you?
answer: Then why did he leave?

question: Well, the same day you were born, something else arrived. It came in the mail, in a box just slightly bigger than you. You know what was in that box? Something called responsibility. Now, to some people, responsibility is fun, it's what you live your whole life for. Other people think it's the scariest thing in the world.
answer: So he ran away because he was scared of what was in the box?

question: Yup.
answer: That's dumb.

question: That's what I thought. Walter, I decided a long time ago that I would always tell you the truth, that I would treat you like a grown-up. I can't expect you to respect me unless I respect you. I've never lied to you. Your father leaving had nothing to do with you, and everything to do with what was in the responsibility box.
answer: Pinky-swear?

question: Pinky-swear. First one to the corner store gets ice cream!
answer: Did I miss Amos and Andy?

question: I'm afraid so, sport. Come on now, time for bed.
answer: Are we still going to the movies tomorrow?

question: Uh-huh. I hear there's a new Charlie Chaplin playing down at Grauman's, and a new serial called The Mysterious Airman.
answer: Who's that?

question: I don't know. Nobody does. That's what makes him so mysterious.
answer: Oh. Am I too heavy for you to carry?

question: Not for years yet, Walter. Not for years. Hello? Oh, hello, Margaret. I'm fine, thanks. No, I was just -- You're kidding. When did she call in sick? What about Myrna? I know she could use the extra hours. Oh. No, it's just...I promised Walter I'd take him to the movies today. There has to be somebody else.... All right, I...guess we can do it tomorrow. I'll get there as soon as I can. But just until four, okay? See you in a bit. There's a sandwich and milk in the icebox, and I've asked Mrs. Riley if her daughter can stop by in a couple of hours, just to --
answer: I can take care of myself.

question: Of course you can. She's coming by to check on the house, not you. Tomorrow, we'll go to the movies. Then we'll ride the Big Red down to Santa Monica and walk on the pier. How's that? That okay?
answer: I'm not afraid of the dark. I'm not afraid of anything.

question: I know you're not, honey. That's how I raised you. Be good. See you in a bit. All right, get me the Omaha routing station, see if we can put the calls through their switchers...and let's get that console running....
answer: Christine...good, I was hoping to catch you. I've been following your work reports, and I just want you to know that I'm very impressed. When I first suggested hiring female supervisors, my superiors weren't big on the idea. But you've held your own as well as any of our male supervisors, and --

question: Thank you, Mr. Harris, but I --
answer: Ben, please. Point is, we're looking for someone to take on a managerial position in our new Beverly Hills office. If you're interested I can --

question: That's great, Mr. Harris, I really appreciate the vote of confidence.
answer: Good, good...so maybe we could --

question: I'm sorry, but I really have to go. We'll talk on Monday. Good night! She races out to Wait...wait...hold on, just a -- Walter? Walter...? Walter? Honey? Time to come in. Susie honey, have you seen Walter? Mrs. Riley, I'm sorry to bother you at dinnertime, but I was wondering if Walter was here.
answer: No, I'm afraid not.

question: Do you know if Jamie was able to look in on him?
answer: Well, I mentioned it to her, but she was going to a dance with some of her friends...you know how teenagers are. Is everything all right?

question: Are you sure you're ready for this, Christine? I mean, if you need more time --
answer: The police are doing all they can, and frankly I could use the money. It's been almost a month, and...it wouldn't do any good to find Walter and bring him home if he doesn't have a home to come back to, right?

question: Of course. Well...I'll leave you to it, then.
answer: Excuse me, can I have your attention? Listen, everyone, I appreciate your consideration, but I'm not made of porcelain. I won't break down and cry if the station to station call to Kankakee doesn't go through. Actually, I...promised myself that I wouldn't cry...wouldn't let myself cry...until I knew, one way or another, what.... Point is...I like the noise here. So don't be afraid to talk and...push buttons, and drop things. If it wasn't noisy, how would I know I was in the right place?

question: Two dollars.
answer: Hell...looks like I left my wallet at home. Can I owe it to you?

question: No credit. Pay up or I call the cops. I'm tired of bums like you coming around here.
answer: I'm not trying to stiff you, chief. I just left my wallet at home, that's all. I'll go back and get it. Five, ten minutes tops.

question: You got any collateral?
answer: Can't ask for better collateral than a man's own flesh and blood, right? You stay here, son, I'll be right back. Now don't give me any trouble. He's a good man to trust us like this. You just sit here while I go get my wallet. Okay?

question: Oh, my, I didn't expect --
answer: We don't get a lot of positive attention from the boys in the press these days, so it's good to be here when there's a positive story, don't you think? I take it you've been treated well by my boys in the department?

question: Oh...yes, of course, they've been great. Well, there was that part about having to wait twenty-four hours before filing a report, but --
answer: Technicalities aside --

question: Yes...other than that, no complaints. They've all been wonderful.
answer: Good, then you won't have any problem telling that to the press, and how the LAPD is concerned first and foremost with the safety of --

question: Women. Just a sec....
answer: Walter...Walter!

question: Well? Aren't you going to --
answer: He's not my son.

question: I...what are you --
answer: He's not my son. He's not my son.

question: I'm...I'm sure you're mistaken.
answer: Mistaken?

question: He's been through four long, terrible months...he's gone through changes, lost weight --
answer: I know my own son.

question: I'm just saying...I mean, you're in shock, and he's changed, and -- What's your name, son? Can you tell me your name?
answer: It's a common name, it --

question: Do you know where you live, Walter? Do you know your home address? Mrs. Collins...listen to me. I know you're feeling uncertain right now, but that's to be expected...a boy this age changes so fast...but we've compensated for that in our investigation. We're experts in child identification. There's no question that this is your son.
answer: It's not Walter.

question: It's not Walter as you remember him. That's why it's important for you to take him home, on a...trial basis.
answer: A trial basis?

question: Once you've put him back in familiar surroundings, and given yourself time to recover from the shock of his changed condition...you'll see that it is him. I swear to you, Mrs. Collins. I give you my word. Trust me...this is your son. If there's any problem, any problem at all, come and talk to me and I'll take care of it. Mrs. Collins...he has nowhere else to go.
answer: I...look, I'll take him home, but only because I...might not be thinking clearly right now, and --

question: Thank you.
answer: It was...it's...hard to explain.

question: Absolutely.
answer: Was the sandwich all right? Would you like some more milk? No, thank you. "WALTER" No, thank you. Now you need a bath. You're covered with soot from the train ride. I found you a pair of pajamas. I bought them for Walter but he didn't like the fabric, so -- Are you all right? Did you hurt yourself? Let me see -- ...circumcised.... The last time I measured Walter -- the last time I measured my son -- he was four inches taller than you are right now. Who are you? What are you doing here? Who are you? He's not my son.

question: Mrs. Collins --
answer: I don't know who he is, or why he's saying he's Walter, but there's clearly been some kind of mistake.

question: We agreed you would give him time to adjust --
answer: He's four inches shorter than Walter. Boys his age don't shrink. If anything, he should be taller.

question: Maybe your measurements are off. Look, I'm sure there's a reasonable explanation for --
answer: He's circumcised. Walter wasn't.

question: Mrs. Collins...your son was missing for four months. For at least part of that in the company of an as-yet unidentified drifter. Who knows what such a disturbed individual might have done? He could have had him...circumcised... might have --
answer: Made him smaller? Captain, please -- -- why won't you listen to me?

question: I am listening, damn it, I -- I am listening. And I understand your feelings. He's changed, no mistake. You've both been through a terrible experience. That's why he needs your support and love to bounce back.
answer: Captain, that boy wouldn't bounce back as my son if you coated him in rubber and dropped him off the roof.

question: Why are you doing this, Mrs. Collins? You seem perfectly capable of taking care of the boy, your work pays you enough to attend to his personal needs...so I don't understand why you're trying to run away from your responsibilities --
answer: I'm not running away from anything, least of all my responsibilities. I'm even taking care of that boy because right now I'm all he has. What worries me is that you've stopped looking for Walter.

question: Why should we look someone we've already found?
answer: But you haven't found him. He's still out there somewhere, lost, maybe hurt....

question: His identity has been confirmed by the best minds in the field of child identification, people who know what they're doing.
answer: And I don't? Captain, look, I don't want to cause trouble for you or the department. Honestly I don't. I know you've done everything you can...but there's been a terrible mistake, and I need your help if we're going to correct it...before it's too late. Please.

question: Mrs. Collins? Dr. Earl W. Tarr. Captain Jones sent me. I consult with him from time to time on juvenile cases. May I come in?
answer: Oh...yes, of course. Thank you for coming. I'm surprised Captain Jones moved so quickly. I was starting to think he didn't believe me.

question: Well, I'm here now, and we'll put all that to rights. Where is the boy? Ah! There he is. A handsome young man. He has your eyes, doesn't he? And a little bit of the nose. Very fit, in spite of all his travails. A very resilient boy you've got here, Mrs. Collins. As he bends down to look more closely at "Walter," Christine stiffens...she can't have heard that right.
answer: Doctor Tarr, I thought you were here to help me.

question: I am. Captain Jones said the boy had gone through some extreme physical changes, and asked me to look in on him...to reassure you in this your time of motherly concern.
answer: My "motherly concern" isn't for him because he's not my son.

question: Statements like that will hardly help the boy's self-esteem, now will they? Captain Jones said something about a change in height...?
answer: He's four inches shorter than --

question: Ah, well...hardly a mystery, Mrs. Collins. We've known for some time that trauma can affect the growth of children. Given the stress of the last four months his spine may have actually shrunk. It's uncommon, but within the realm of possibility.
answer: What about the circumcision?

question: Very likely his abductor thought it appropriate. After all, circumcision is hygienically sound. Must have been quite traumatic at the time. No wonder he's submerged the memory.
answer: Look, doctor --

question: As you can see, there's a perfectly sound medical explanation for all of this. But it's good for you to raise these questions. You should be apprised of all changes the lad went through during his absence.
answer: Wouldn't I know whether or not he was my son? I'm his mother.

question: Which means you're in no position to be objective. You are looking through the prism of extreme emotion at a boy who has changed from what you remember. He isn't the same boy that left here, just as a boy who goes off to war and returns isn't the same anymore.
answer: What're you --

question: Hello, children, my name is Dr. Earl W. Tarr. I'd like to ask you some questions. Good boy. Quite right. But as you see I'm with the police, so it's all right. Now, I'm sure you know Mrs. Collins here, and her son, Walter. How many of you recognize this young boy as Walter Collins? Now, now, no need to be afraid. Surely you knew Walter, and played with him? So which of you can identify Walter for me, for his mother, and for the police? This officer would want you to do the right thing as good young citizens. Yes, precisely. He was as tall as you. Now he's not. He's lost a little height, you see. It's a thing called trauma. With luck, none of you will ever have to find out about it yourselves. So other than that, do you recognize this as your friend, Walter Collins?
answer: Dr. Tarr --

question: Already ahead of you, Mrs. Collins; children can be intimidated. But not adults. Shall we try a neighbor? -- and we'd appreciate it if you could make a positive identification for us.
answer: I'd be happy to. I saw the boy often. Come closer, son.

question: Take your time...be sure.
answer: Oh, yes...yes...that's Walter all right. Used to come here all the time to play with my nephew, Roger.

question: Captain Jones promised he'd let me see the report before it went anywhere else.
answer: Someone in authority at the LAPD lied? Good heavens, I may have to go lie down. I was not laughing at your situation, Mrs. Collins. It's just...after one has this sort of conversation enough times, a certain degree of hysteria begins to set in. Please, sit. Reluctantly, she does. Shakes her head in disbelief.

question: Why are they doing this?
answer: To avoid admitting a mistake...that they brought back the wrong boy. Anyone reading that with half a brain would see through it instantly. Sadly, that leaves out about half the Times' readership, but still....

question: Thank you.
answer: You have no idea how many people have sat in that very chair and said those exact same words to me in relation to our friends at the Los Angeles Police Department. Mrs. Collins, I have made it my mission to bring to light all the things the LAPD would prefer no one knew anything about...a department ruled by violence, abuse, murder, corruption and intimidation. When Chief Davis took over the LAPD two years ago, he said --

question: This police department does not tolerate dissent, contradiction... or embarrassment, Mrs. Collins. You have the power to embarrass them...and they don't like it. Not when they became the Heroes of the Hour the day they stood there posing with you, having rescued a lost boy from the wilderness.
answer: Reverend Briegleb...I appreciate what you're saying, and what you're doing...but I'm not on a mission. The only thing I want is to find my son, that's all, and I just --

question: A lot of mothers' sons ended up being sacrificed to expediency around here, Mrs. Collins. Yours wouldn't be the first. Do this right, and maybe yours will be the last.
answer: If they honestly thought I was wrong, that'd be one thing...but if they don't care, if they're just trying to cover it up....

question: This is their attempt to win by framing the discussion their way. "Why, of course it's her son...yes, there have been changes...we're looking into it, and isn't it strange that they happened after the boy got home?" They're putting you in the position of having to disprove what they're saying...and that's hard. Most people believe what they hear from the police or the government. If you play it their way, you...and your son...are going to lose.
answer: What do I have to do?

question: Change the rules of engagement. Re- define the argument. They brought in their expert, so you bring in yours. You have an advantage they don't. You know your son better than they ever will, and in that knowledge is the proof you need. Get that information, put it out there. Make them respond to you, not the other way around. Once people side with the police, it's a hard climb...but even in a town as loud as this one, the voice of truth can be heard...if you're willing to take it all the way in spite of the dangers...and they are very real, Mrs. Collins, make no mistake. Once you open the book on these people, you're going to be looking over your shoulder every day, maybe for the rest of your life. You up to it, Mrs. Collins?
answer: Well?

question: Well?
answer: He had two cavities that needed filling. He put up a fight, but I took care of it.

question: And...?
answer: Your son's upper front teeth were separated by a small muscle. Made them sit about an eighth of an inch apart. The boy in that room has no such gap.

question: Does a gap like that get smaller with age? Because that's what they'll say.
answer: In some cases, yes, it's possible. But the muscle between Walter's teeth prevents that from happening. They can never come together without an operation to sever the muscle, and I can tell you right now that he has never had such an operation.

question: Will you be willing to sign a letter saying that officially?
answer: Pardon my language, but...hell, yes. Sounds like the anesthetic is wearing off. On the other hand, maybe I'll write that letter first. Give the little fella something to think about. He smiles.

question: Mrs. Collins. Leave the boy for now. We'll look after him. You've put us through quite a bit of trouble, Mrs. Collins. This situation has become an embarrassment for the entire department.
answer: It wasn't my intention to embarrass anyone.

question: No, of course not. You just told the papers we can't tell one boy from another as a compliment for the months we spent working on your case. Are you trying to make fools out of us? Is that it? Do you enjoy this?
answer: No, of course not. I had to get your attention, I had to make you understand...he's not my son.

question: You know what your problem is? You want to shirk your responsibilities as a mother. You enjoyed being a free woman, didn't you? Enjoyed not having to worry about a young son. You could do what you wanted, go where you wanted, see anyone you wanted. But then we found your son. Brought him back. And now he's an inconvenience. That's why you cooked up this whole scheme, to try and throw him to the state, let the state raise him for you.
answer: That's not true!

question: No? Even the boy says he's your son. Why would he do that? How would he know to do that?
answer: I don't know! All I know is that he's lying!

question: Maybe so. Maybe he is a liar. But that's how he's been trained, isn't it? Lying was born in both of you. You're a liar and a troublemaker and if you ask me you've got no business walking the streets of Los Angeles.
answer: Just a minute --

question: Because either you know you're lying, or you're not capable of knowing if you're lying or telling the truth. So which is it, Mrs. Collins? Are you a derelict mother? Or just nuts? Because from where I sit, those are the only options.
answer: I'm not going to sit here and take this --

question: You want to bring in experts? Doctors? Well, I can do that too. Matron? Mrs. Collins...do you still insist that the boy out there is not your son?
answer: Yes. Wait...what are you doing?

question: Please...you have to listen to me. The police are doing this to punish me. They tried to force this boy on me and tell me he was my son, but it wasn't my son, and now they say I'm crazy -- Oh, god...oh god, please, no....
answer: If you continue to struggle I'll have to put you in a straitjacket. Do you want that? Good. Then behave yourself. Code twelve.

question: No, please, you have to listen to me...wait...please!
answer: Take off your clothes.

question: Why?
answer: Physical examination, body cavity search and de-lousing. Required for all new patients.

question: That's not necessary --
answer: You can remove your clothes yourself, or I can have the orderlies do it for you. Which do you prefer? Spread your legs. Wider. Inside. This is your room. The doctor's left for the day. He'll see you in the morning.

question: The morning? But...wait, I've got to talk to someone in authority --
answer: Sorry.

question: Then if I could just use the phone.
answer: Phone privileges are earned by good behavior. You're not allowed newspapers, magazines, radio, books or sharp objects. This is for your own good.

question: Problem?
answer: Overheated, that's all. She'll be fine in a bit.

question: Listen, could you give me a hand? I'm trying to find a place called the Northcott Ranch, up by Wineville.
answer: Northcott Ranch...oh yeah. You're almost there. Follow this west for about two, three miles. Then the next right. That'll bring you right to it. Something going on?

question: This is the police. I have a warrant for a minor named Sanford Clark. Open the door and stand aside. Stop it! Stop it or I'll push your face through the floor! On your feet. Jesus...what the hell's wrong with you? Don't you know assaulting a cop is against the law?
answer: What difference does it make now?

question: We're just sending you back to Canada, son, it isn't the end of the world.
answer: What?

question: You should eat. Eating is normal. You got to do everything you can to look normal. That's the only chance you've got. Besides, you'll need the strength. My name's Carol Dexter. What's yours?
answer: Christine. Christine Collins.

question: Finish it all. I know it's hard, but you have to try. Lunch isn't as bad. Close, but not as --
answer: I won't be here that long. As soon as I can talk to a doctor, they'll realize there's been a terrible mistake and --

question: Yeah, that always works. I heard them talking. You're here on a code twelve, police action. The doctors, the staff, they figure that if the police sent you here, there must be a good reason for it.
answer: Then I'll just have to prove that I'm not insane.

question: Yeah? How? The more you try to act sane, the crazier you start to look. If you smile too much, you're delusional or stifling hysteria. If you don't smile, you're depressed. If you're neutral you're emotionally withdrawn and potentially catatonic.
answer: You seem to have given this a great deal of thought.

question: I have. Don't you get it? You're code twelve. So am I. We're here for the same reason. We pissed off the cops. What, you thought you were the only one? The lady over there was married to a cop who kept beating her up. When she tried to tell somebody, they sent her here. And that one? The police beat the crap out of her brother, broke both his arms. When she complained to the papers, they picked her up and...
answer: What about you?

question: I...work nights. I mean, I work nights. Downtown. In some of the clubs. You know. This one client started hitting me, and he wouldn't stop. So I filed a complaint. Turns out he was a cop. Next thing I know, I'm here.
answer: But how can they --

question: Clark...Sanford Clark. Paperwork's come through. You'll be deported back to Canada day after tomorrow. The police there will to decide what to do with you next. I hope your stay here has convinced you not to try crossing the border illegally in future.
answer: Wait, I...I want to talk to the officer who brought me in.

question: I'm sure he has far more important things to do than --
answer: Please. It's important.

question: Mrs. Collins...Dr. Jonathan Steele. Please, have a seat. I hope your stay has been comfortable so far.
answer: Fine. Thank you.

question: Really? I'd think it would be quite difficult at first.
answer: Well, it was. Difficult, I mean. But comfortable.

question: I see they took a blood test.
answer: Wasserman Test. To check for syphilis. Apparently it can affect the mind.

question: The idea that someone thinks you should be checked for syphilis...did that upset you?
answer: No. Not at all. I'm sure it's... standard procedure.

question: Yes. Exactly. Standard procedure. We have to cover all bases, and --
answer: But...at the same time...I imagine that it would be...would probably be upsetting to...some people that someone else might...suspect that of them. However inappropriate that might be.

question: According to your file, you believe the police have substituted a fake boy for your son. Is that true?
answer: I didn't say they substituted a fake boy, just...not the right boy. They brought back the wrong boy. Not my son. He's still missing.

question: That's strange...you see, I have here a newspaper article with a photo of you at the train station, welcoming your son home. That is you in the photo, isn't it?
answer: Yes.

question: So at first he was your son, but now he's not your son. Has this been going on for a long time? People...changing, becoming something other than what they are?
answer: People don't change, doctor.

question: You don't think people change?
answer: That's not what I --

question: And the police...they're not out to persecute you?
answer: No. Of course not.

question: The police are here to protect us.
answer: That's right.

question: It's raining cats, dogs and democrats out there, so this better be worth it. Well?
answer: Look, I -- this isn't easy, okay?

question: Nothing is.
answer: My cousin's Gordon Northcott. He owns the ranch where you found me. He let me live there in exchange for watching the place when he was gone, doing chores, stuff like that. Said I could stay on as long as I wanted to. I figured that also meant I could leave whenever I wanted to, but he wouldn't let me.

question: Are you saying he held you prisoner? Bull. When I got to the ranch you were running around free as a jaybird. Could've left any time you wanted. So what's this, some kind of story to cover why you were in the country illegally?
answer: No...no, it's nothing like that.

question: Because I don't have time for --
answer: Listen to me, please. He said --

question: What? What did he --
answer: He said that if I tried to leave, he'd kill me!

question: Okay, lets start at the beginning. What did he make you do?
answer: Him and me...me and Gordon, we... ...we killed some kids. I didn't mean to, I swear...he made me help him, said if I didn't he'd kill me, too. Please, you gotta help me...I'm scared...I don't want to go to Hell for killing kids.

question: What kids?
answer: I don't know...I never knew their names.

question: How many kids?
answer: All together? About...twenty, I guess.

question: You're lying.
answer: No, it's true, I swear!

question: Twenty kids.
answer: Yeah...thereabouts...I kinda stopped counting after a while, and Gordon said one or two might've gotten away, but --

question: Nobody can just up and kill twenty kids --
answer: We did...yeah, we did that....

question: How?
answer: Most times we'd bring back just one or two...sometimes as many as three. I always knew when he was getting ready 'cause he'd go through the car and clean it up, make sure the tires were good, the engine...he was always afraid something'd break down and we'd be caught.

question: Most times we'd bring back just one or two...sometimes as many as three. I always knew when he was getting ready 'cause he'd go through the car and clean it up, make sure the tires were good, the engine...he was always afraid something'd break down and we'd be caught.
answer: Time to go.

question: We'd go a different direction every time, never hit the same part of town twice. Sometimes we'd go for hours, just driving around, until we found somebody. He'd use all kinds of different stories. Sometimes he'd say he had free tickets for the circus, or he was looking for a lost dog...that one worked real good. Other days --
answer: There you are, we've been looking for you like mad. Sure thing. Your folks, they got in an accident. They sent us to find you. They're hurt real bad. The police took 'em to the hospital, but they didn't have time to come find you, so we said we'd do it. Now come on, hurry...we gotta get to the hospital, see your folks.

question: A lot of kids won't get in a car alone with a stranger, but when he's got a kid there with him, that made it easier. They'd look to me, and figure if I was safe, they would be too. That's why he needed me, see? It's okay. Come on in. Every time they got in the truck, it was like I wanted to die.
answer: Good boy! Now hold on, it's a long drive and we gotta fly.

question: These...uhm...these kids...do you think...if you saw them again, do you think you'd recognize them? Just a second. I haven't updated these in a while, but still, it should be.... Just go through...and if you see any faces you recognize, put it on the table. ...shit.... The name on the back of the photo is WALTER COLLINS.
answer: He's lying. Have you gone soft in the head, Les?

question: Sir, I --
answer: He's playing you! He knows he's in trouble, so he's come up with some cock and bull story about how he was forced to stay in the country --

question: With all due respect, sir, I don't think so. You didn't see him, the kid's scared half out of his mind --
answer: He picked the Collins kid! We found him, remember? Haven't you been reading the papers? Or maybe you have, is that it?

question: Sir, if you'd just listen --
answer: Tell the sonofabitch to get the hell off police property before I have him arrested for disturbing the peace. What the hell...? Jesus jumped down.... Ybarra? Listen. You're not to do anything except come back here.

question: Sir, department policy requires that all allegations of homicide have to be investigated. And these are kids, for chrissakes --
answer: Departmental policy is what I say it is, you got that? Now I'm ordering you to get your ass back here with that kid, you got that? You bring him here and you talk to no one, got it? Nobody!

question: Are you Captain Jones?
answer: I am.

question: What the hell have you done with Christine Collins? Don't try and lie your way out of it. I talked to several neighbors who saw her being driven off in a police car.
answer: Mrs. Collins has been placed in protective custody following a mental breakdown.

question: A what?!
answer: Her statements and behavior have been found to be consistent with a delusional state of mind that could make her a danger to herself or others. In the public interest, we are looking after her son while she gets the help she clearly needs.

question: Where?
answer: Sorry, we're withholding that information to respect the privacy of the family. But I can assure you that she's getting the best treatment available. That's all.

question: What for? What kind of medication? I don't want to relax...I'm fine, and I won't take something unless I know what it is!
answer: Orderly --

question: Just listen --
answer: -- we can force-feed it to you if that's what you want.

question: Doctor...Doctor Steele --
answer: I heard.

question: I don't know what's going on, but I'm not taking anything until --
answer: I understand. Come with me.

question: I don't have anything wrong with me that I should have to take medication.
answer: There's nothing wrong with you.

question: That's right.
answer: You're fine.

question: Yes.
answer: Then you shouldn't have any trouble signing this. By signing, you certify that you were wrong when you stated the boy returned by the police was not your son. It further stipulates that the police acted properly in sending you here for observation and absolves them of all responsibility for --

question: I won't sign it.
answer: Then your condition is not improved. Sign it, and you can be out of here first thing tomorrow.

question: I won't sign it! I was not wrong! That boy is not my son! And I am not going to stop telling the truth about this! And you're not going to stop me, and the police aren't going to stop me --
answer: Mrs. Collins, you're becoming agitated.

question: -- I will tear down the walls of this place with my bare hands if I have to, but one way or another --
answer: Orderly! The patient is disturbed, hyperactive and is threatening the staff. See to it she is properly sedated.

question: No! No, I won't let you! Someone, please, help me!
answer: Stay out of this! This is none of your business! This is police business! You'll stay out of it if you know what's good for you! You'd think you had enough trouble with the law just being a whore, wouldn't you? Attacking a staff member. Room eighteen. Electro-convulsive therapy.

question: You shouldn't have done that.
answer: Wanted...to. Felt...good. I lost...two babies...to back alley doctors...no choice.... Never had...the chance...to fight for them. You do. Don't stop.

question: I won't...I won't.
answer: Fuck them...and the horse...they rode in on.

question: That's hardly appropriate language for a lady, now is it?
answer: Hell, yeah...there are times...that's exactly the right thing to say.

question: And when's that?
answer: When you've got...nothing left to lose.

question: WHO'S IN CHARGE HERE!
answer: I'm head doctor on duty. What's the problem?

question: You the doctor who's got Christine Collins locked up in here? Intercut with:
answer: Sorry, we don't discuss our cases with anyone other than family --

question: You'll damned well discuss this one with me!
answer: Sir --

question: Mrs. Collins. One last time. Are you, or are you not, prepared to sign that letter?
answer: No.

question: You're free to go.
answer: ...what?

question: Your clothes are in the next room. You can change there.
answer: Next door.

question: You're getting out?
answer: I am out.

question: How --
answer: I don't know...but I couldn't go without saying goodbye --

question: Christine, don't be stupid, get out of here fast in case they change their mind.
answer: I will...but I want you to know

question: You are crazy.
answer: Watch me.

question: I don't know if you're aware of it, Captain, but I have an exceptionally good vocabulary. I'm a terror at Scrabble, crossword puzzles, but even I'm in awe of the vocabulary that the press and the city council have been exercising in reference to this department courtesy of the Christine Collins...incident. Incompetent. Cowardly. Bullying. Reprehensible. Mendacious and invidious...those two courtesy of that prick Gustav Briegleb. Bonus words in Scrabble, both of them. Especially invidious. Hard to work that one into a conversation. But he managed it, all right.
answer: Sir, I --

question: The key, of course, is the context in which words like this get used. You have to do that in scrabble, you know, when somebody challenges a word...show how it's used in a sentence. So "incompetent," as in -- "A department so incompetent that they never realized that up to twenty children were being kidnapped and murdered under their very noses." And here Captain, your handling of the Collins case has exposed this department to public ridicule. There is even the potential for civil and criminal liability.
answer: Sir, nobody could have known what was going on up at that ranch. Not us, not the Sheriff's Department, the Marshall's Office...as for the Collins woman.... I'm still not convinced that her kid is among the victims up in Wineville.

question: No?
answer: No, sir.

question: Maybe he was...which raises the obvious question
answer: Sir?

question: The Mayor wants this to go away. I want this to go away. The way you do that is to stop insisting that Walter Collins was not among those kids killed up at that goddamned ranch. Because if the boy you brought back isn't Walter Collins, and he's not dead up at that ranch, then where the hell is he? People will want to know why we haven't found him. Why we aren't we doing our job. But if, on the other hand, he is, or could be among those poor boys killed up in Wineville...then the inquiries stop. It's a momentary embarrassment that you'll have to live with...but better a short inconvenience than a lingering problem, wouldn't you say, Captain? Jones doesn't like it, but he swallows his pride. Nods.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: The boy's been gone for nearly a year. If he was going to be found, it would've happened by now. Whether he was up at that ranch or not, the truth is he probably is dead somewhere. Better his mother accepts that now rather than later, don't you think?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Good. That'll be all, Captain.
answer: Sir, there's talk of an investigation by the police commission.

question: Let me worry about the commission. But it wouldn't hurt to find out just who the fuck that kid is you brought back from De Kalb and why he did this, because the press bought into his bullshit same as we did. That we were all taken in by the scheming little bastard may help take some of the sting off this.
answer: My boys are working on it now, sir.

question: My boys are working on it now, sir.
answer: Tough. What's your name? Walter Collins is dead. Look, let me explain something to you. Because of your lies, you've ruined a woman's life embarrassed the police department, and got the whole city up in arms over this. All right, if that's how you want it, then I guess we're done here. Tell County Jail we're remanding him for trial. I told you, the real Walter Collins was murdered. By pretending to be Walter Collins, you're interfering in a police investigation of a kidnapping and murder. We can try you as an accomplice to murder after the fact. Too bad. County Jail is a lot worse than juvenile hall or a foster home. A lot worse. Sanford Clark is a kid, too. Fifteen. But he's going to jail. All murderers and their accomplices go to jail. Everyone knows that. Get him out of here. It's out of my hands now. Prove it. Arthur Hutchins. The boy's real name is Arthur Hutchins Junior, age twelve, a runaway from Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

question: Did you check the wire services?
answer: Checks out. The report was filed by his divorced mother, who lives in Clinton, Iowa with the boy's grandmother. Apparently he didn't like living with the old lady, she didn't let him get away with the stuff he usually got away with, and one day...he up and left.

question: What about the man he showed up with at the diner?
answer: Just some drifter. The boy was hungry, ran into this guy who said he knew how to get some food and not have to pay for it. Only when they finished, he left the kid behind while he cut out. When the police picked him up, they started going through the wire reports about missing kids --

question: And he overheard them say the name Walter Collins.
answer: Bingo.

question: But why that one? I mean, of all the police departments he could've screwed up, why Los Angeles?
answer: I asked him the same question.

question: How are you feeling?
answer: A little better, thanks. The sleep helped. Anything new outside?

question: Nothing that can't wait until you're stronger. The police still have a car parked outside. They want to know what your next move is.
answer: I want to go home.

question: And then?
answer: I've been giving that a great deal of thought ever since I got out of that...place. All those women, and what they did about Walter.... They're going to just keep on doing it, aren't they? Nothing's going to change...unless we make it change. I used to tell Walter, "Never start a fight...but always finish it." I didn't start this fight...but by god I'm going to finish it.

question: It's dangerous, and you've already been through a great deal, Mrs. Collins. Right now you're sufficiently high-profile that the police will hesitate to come after you out in the open...but if they see their position threatened, that could change quickly. Your life could be in danger.
answer: "Always finish it. Always."

question: Just a minute....
answer: Hi, sis.

question: Gordon...I didn't know you were back in town.
answer: Got in a couple of days ago, figured I'd surprise you. That okay?

question: Yes...yes, of course. Come on in.
answer: Where's that little niece of mine?

question: She...went into town. Should be back this evening. Bob's here --
answer: Good. Need to talk to him about staying on for a few days.

question: Staying --
answer: Listen, can I use your bathroom? It's been a long ride and I could use a shower.

question: Yes...of course. Mr. Hahn, was it?
answer: Yes.

question: I appreciate the sentiment, but so far they still haven't positively identified any of the...remains... as Walter's.
answer: But he was identified, was he not?

question: Yes, but...I guess I still can't accept it. It doesn't feel real to me.
answer: It never does. I lost a daughter to polio five years ago. There's not a day goes by I don't think, I should mention this to Claudine... then I remember she's not here.

question: I'm sorry. Please, sit. I've been on the phone all day with the appointment secretary for the police commission. They won't let me testify at the hearing, or call witnesses. They say it's not necessary.
answer: I know. My sources tell me the police commission is going to come out with a report that whitewashes the whole thing. They're going to say that Jones and the rest of the LAPD did absolutely nothing wrong, that the real blame is with the kid...and with you, for being difficult and forcing them to put you away for your own safety.

question: Then we'll just have to hire a lawyer...bring a civil suit and try to get the City Council to call for a hearing by the Welfare Board.
answer: Jut one problem.

question: Of course. Where downtown?
answer: Yes? May I --

question: My name is S. S.
answer: I'm sorry, but the doctor in charge won't be in until tomorrow morning and --

question: Mr. Northcott, any comment on your arrest?
answer: I'm feeling fine.

question: How did you avoid capture?
answer: Well, I didn't, did I? Didn't know anyone wanted me until just recently. Didn't even try. My luggage still has my initials on it. No, but I figured it would be best if I stayed out of it.

question: Anything to say to the parents of the children you murdered?
answer: No comment.

question: Mayor Cryer...this is unexpected.
answer: So was this. Subpoenas, requests for depositions, interrogatories...all courtesy of Mr. Hahn and his new client, Christine Collins.

question: Goddamnit....
answer: I thought this was supposed to go away. This is an election year, I can't afford this kind of press.

question: It is going away, sir. I instructed Captain Jones --
answer: I'm afraid falling on his sword and saying he made a mistake isn't going to be good enough, Chief. If we take him out of the picture for a while, it might help calm things down until the hearing's finished. There are several people on the council who are planning to run against me, and they'd love to accuse me of allowing a renegade police force to operate with impunity. Our friends in the press are having a field day with this mess. I'm getting five hundred phone calls, letters and telegrams a day demanding to know what the hell is going on at City Hall that we allow our police force to brutalize women and misplace children. Christ, all this picture needs now is for somebody to kick a puppy for the cameras. This is a train, Chief, and we need to either get in front of it, or be run over by it.

question: Mayor Cryer...I stand by my men. You know that.
answer: I do. And you know where I stand. So the question is..are we going to stand together...or hang together?

question: Reverend, what --
answer: Sorry to barge in so late, Mrs. Collins, but it took me a while to find the right people for the right job. These three gentlemen are members of my congregation who, before coming to the Lord, had lived lives of brutality, vice and crime. Now they are pledged to doing god's work...and if this isn't it, I don't know what is.

question: I don't understand.
answer: People who bring charges against the police have a habit of

question: I see...well, I...thank you. Can I get you anything?
answer: Since we don't plan on sleeping, coffee would be lovely. Traffic's getting heavy. We'll go up Spring. Hold on. Start walking. Quickly.

question: The boy, Walter Collins, was reported as missing on March 10, 1928. We then instituted a nationwide search. On July 10, we received a cable indicating that a boy matching his description had been found in De Kalb, Illinois. Upon questioning, he admitted to being Walter Collins, and we made arrangements to transport him back to California.
answer: Where Mrs. Collins told you the boy was not her son.

question: Yes. She denied his identity in spite of all evidence pointing to the contrary.
answer: But as subsequent events have demonstrated, she was correct. So what prompted you to send her for psychological evaluation?

question: Whether or not this was in fact the correct boy was not relevant to my decision. Throughout this period, she acted strangely. She was often cool, aloof and unemotional, especially when presented with the boy we located in De Kalb, and in our subsequent conversations. It was because of her disturbing behavior that I submitted her for observation to the psychopathic ward of Los Angeles County General Hospital.
answer: Just like that. You snap your fingers and an innocent woman is thrown into the psycho ward.

question: She wasn't --
answer: Every home in this state is in grave danger when a Police Captain can take a woman into his office and, five minutes later, have her thrown into the psychopathic ward on his own authority!

question: She wasn't --
answer: What was that, Captain?

question: She wasn't thrown. She was... escorted.
answer: Escorted, thrown, the verb doesn't matter, Captain. What does matter is that her incarceration was ordered without a warrant. I am holding a carbon copy of the affidavit of insanity that was issued in the case of the State of California vs. Christine Collins. Who signed the affidavit?

question: I did.
answer: And what is the date on this document?

question: September 12th.
answer: But Mrs. Collins was incarcerated on September 6th.

question: The form is backdated.
answer: Yes, so it would appear. The bottom of the page is reserved for recording where and when the warrant was served. But it has not been filled in. May I assume from this that the warrant was never served?

question: That's correct. There was no need to serve the warrant since she was at that time already in custody.
answer: Let me see if I have this straight. A woman was thrown into the psychopathic ward without a warrant, because no warrant existed, and when it was finally written six days later, there was no need to sign it or go to a judge because

question: Technically...yes. Extraordinary steps were necessary because we were dealing with an extraordinary situation! Is it our fault that we were being deceived by the boy who claimed to be Walter Collins? No. In light of his claims and her behavior, who wouldn't begin to wonder if there was something wrong with her?
answer: Because she questioned you.

question: Because she wouldn't listen, because she insisted on being obstinate and taking matters into her own hands best left to qualified officers, because --
answer: Because she was fighting for the life of her son! A boy who may have still been alive while you were wasting valuable time denying you had done anything wrong! And in the end, that's what happened, isn't it? At some point, while all this was going on, Walter Collins died along with as many as nineteen other youths on the Northcott Ranch in Wineville. Is that correct, Captain?

question: Yes. It is.
answer: No further questions.

question: I'm up here, Reverend. When Walter was...when he was here, I'd walk past his bedroom when he was asleep, and even if I couldn't see him, or hear him, I could...feel him in here.
answer: Mothers and their children are connected in amazing ways. My uncle joined the army during the big war, and the day he died, before we ever heard a word about it, my grandmother woke up in the middle of the night and said, "Bobby's gone." She just...knew.

question: That's why I don't think Walter is dead. I can still feel him, in this room.
answer: Mrs. Collins --

question: I know what the police said. But the remains...what they found on that ranch is so...most of it can't even be properly identified. What if that boy made a mistake when he picked Walter's picture?
answer: I understand that you don't want to accept this. What mother does? But you have to let go...and start over. For yourself. He'd want you to move on.

question: Maybe. And maybe he'd want me to keep looking. Maybe he's waiting for me, somewhere.
answer: He is, Christine. We should go.

question: This meeting will now come to order. This Committee has now heard all of the testimony, and in light of the facts presented, issues the following statement.
answer: Mr. Foreman, has the jury reached a verdict?

question: While the City Council has no power to directly remove commissioners or
answer: Bailiff, will you bring me the verdict of the jury?

question: Second, we recommend that the suspension of Captain Jones be made permanent.
answer: Will the defendant please rise?

question: Third, that steps be taken to investigate a change in the prevailing laws and procedures by
answer: You may read the verdict. Does the defendant wish to make a statement before judgment is passed?

question: We'll see. Thanks, Ben. Yes, hello, this is Christine Collins, we spoke yesterday about my son...fine, thank you. I was wondering if you'd had a chance to go through the file on runaways in your area in case anyone resembling Walter had -- I see. No, thank you, I appreciate the information. Would it be all right if I called you again, in a month or so? Thank you. Goodbye.
answer: Mrs. Collins.

question: Oh, hello, I was just --
answer: I know. That's...why I wanted to see you. It's about Walter. We had...well, we received a very strange telegram.

question: From who?
answer: Gordon Northcott. He's...he's asked to see you.

question: Why?
answer: He said he knows you're still looking for your son, and before he dies -- He says that he lied when he testified that he didn't kill Walter. He's willing to finally admit that he did it. He says that if you come up to see him, in person...he'll tell you the truth, to your face...so that you can get on with your life and have some peace. As you know, he's set to be executed the day after tomorrow at San Quentin, so.... You don't have a lot of time. Took me most of the morning to make all the arrangements. Turns out you're the first woman in thirty years the state has allowed to visit a serial killer on the night of his execution.

question: No, I'm...sure I'll be fine.
answer: Don't suppose you've got a cigarette?

question: No, I don't smoke.
answer: That's where they do it, you know. That building right over there.

question: That's where they do what?
answer: The hangings. Ten o'clock tonight, I get to see what's inside. I hear there's thirteen steps going up to the gallows...'cause thirteen is unlucky. Helps make sure you're gonna go to hell when you die. But I got 'em beat. I outsmarted 'em. They're gonna let me have whatever I want for dinner. Got a steak coming, with spinach, mashed potatoes and green beans. I always wondered why they did that whole last meal thing. One of the other guys on Death Row said when you take the drop, you foul yourself, and everything you ate...comes out the other end. So maybe that's why they make sure you got something in you when it happens. They like knowing you fouled yourself on the way to -- Sure you don't got a cigarette? The warden, Clinton Duffy, he's a good guy. He's writing a book about all the death sentences he's carried out in this place. Says it's called "Eighty-Eight Men and Two Women." Beats my record all to hell.

question: Mr. Northcott...you asked me to come to see you. You said if I did, you would tell me the truth about my son. Well, I'm here.
answer: Yeah...yeah, you are. But see, the thing is, I didn't think you'd really come, and now --

question: Now what?
answer: I didn't expect.... I don't want to see you.

question: What?
answer: I can't do this...I can't talk to you...not today, not tonight, not with what they're going to do to me. It's one thing to send a telegram, that's easy, but right now, right here, in person, I -- I can't tell you what you want to hear, Mrs. Collins. I can't, I can't --

question: Why not?
answer: Because I don't want to die with a lie on my lips! I did my penance, I asked God to forgive me for my sins...and I've been good, ever since...if I commit a sin now, if I lie now...I'm out of time, I can't be forgiven again... I don't want to go to hell --

question: Mr. Northcott...look at me. Look at me. Did you...kill...my son?
answer: Get away from me...I don't know anything about it!

question: Mr. Northcott --
answer: I'm innocent! Guard! Guard!

question: No, wait, please -- Did you kill him? Did you kill my son? Mr. Northcott...Mr. Northcott!
answer: No...nothing. I kept clean after I confessed, reverend...just like I said I would. Will it...will it hurt? Please...not so fast...don't make me walk so fast! Thirteen steps...thirteen steps... but I didn't touch all of 'em, you bastards...I didn't touch all of 'em! A prayer! Please, somebody, say a prayer for me! Silent night...holy night...all is calm...all is bright...round yon virgin mother and child...holy infant so tender and mild --

question: Hey, Chris...we're having an Oscar party tonight at my apartment, you want to come?
answer: I can't...I've got a million forms to fill out --

question: C'mon, please, they can wait --
answer: Sandy, you guys blew out the phone lines between here and Baltimore, someone has to clean up the mess, and that's me. Besides, I've got a radio right here, I can follow the whole thing.

question: You're sure?
answer: Positive. Go on, have fun. I said I can't go --

question: Positive. Go on, have fun. I said I can't go --
answer: Are you sure? I'm meeting some friends for dinner at Musso and Frank's on Hollywood. They're going to pipe the Oscar ceremony through to the restaurant. Should be quite a night. I'd love it if you'd come.

question: Ben, that's very sweet, and I wish I could...but I really need to stay and finish this. Ben...? I put down two dollars on "It Happened One Night" for best picture. Seems I'm the only one here who thinks it has a chance against "Cleopatra." If I win, how about we have dinner tomorrow night to celebrate?
answer: You've got a deal, Christine. Good night.

question: 'Night.
answer: How about I call you if you win?

question: Were there other boys present?
answer: Yeah...six, I think. It was a long time ago.

question: Did you speak to them? Do you remember any of their names?
answer: Yeah...two of them were brothers, I think their last name was Winslow, something like that. The oldest was Jeffrey, I think he was around eleven.... ...and Walter.

question: Walter.
answer: Yeah.

question: Do you remember his last name?
answer: Collins.

question: So if you only remember some of the names of the rest, how come you remember his full name?
answer: Because of what happened. Walter and Jeffrey were talking when everybody else was screaming. They were scared, same as the rest of us, but they weren't scared stupid. They kept checking around until they found a part of the coop where the chicken wire was all messed up. They figured we might be able to yank the chicken wire and bring down the corner, maybe make enough room to get out of there and run... but it would make an awful lot of noise and if it wasn't wide enough, we'd be stuck. It might even bring the whole place down.

question: Help! Hurry!
answer: And that's the last you saw of him?

question: That's the last I saw of any of 'em.
answer: So you don't know if either of the other two were captured?

question: No. All I know is, if he hadn't come back for me...I don't think I ever would've gotten out of there.
answer: What happened after that?

question: I hid in the woods for two days, too scared to move, because I was sure they'd find me. I finally started walking, but every time a car came up I was afraid it was them. So I kept off the main roads until I saw a train stopped at a crossing, and I jumped in.
answer: Why didn't you tell anyone what had happened?

question: I was afraid! I thought they'd come after me, or my folks...so I didn't tell anybody. I was on my own until I got a free meal from this lady, Mrs. Lansing. I told her I was an orphan, on my own. She said I could stay on, and...I did. Every night, I'd wake up, thinking they were right outside my window. Then I heard the police talking on the radio about what happened at the ranch, and I thought, for sure I can't go back now.
answer: Why not?

question: Since I didn't tell anybody what happened, I was afraid they'd blame me for those kids being dead. So I just...stayed away.
answer: So what made you come forward now, after all this time?

question: I miss my mom...I miss my dad...I just...I just want to go home.
answer: Still can't believe it. Five years, case closed, everyone thinks he's dead...and there he is.
